verified_reviews: The Echo is an amazing device.  Many times it seems very intuitive.  But at other times I ask for something that seems clear and simple and get no result.  Installation was fairly straightforward, but I messed up several times simply because I thought a step was complete when it wasn't.  This actually made me lose ground until I figured that out.  My advice is to be patient; the app will let you know when you can move on to the next step.My biggest issue of the moment is that we have several Echo devices in our home and I would like to use them as intercoms (which I am told can be done).  However, I can't make any of the Echos aware of the others existence.  When I ask Alexa how to do this she answers about instructions how to change her name.  I know this is likely my fault, but I would think the designers would anticipate this and make it easier to find the needed instructions.  A small deal for many device savvy people, but a challenge for me.
paraphrased_reviews: The Echo is a remarkable piece of technology which often appears to be quite intuitive. However, there have been occasions where I have asked for something which appears to be straightforward yet I receive no response. The installation process was not too difficult, but I did make a few mistakes because I assumed the step was finished when it wasn't. My recommendation would be to be patient; the app will let you know when you can move on to the next step. At the moment, I am having difficulty getting the Echo devices in my home to function as intercoms, something I have been told is possible. When I ask Alexa for help, she responds with instructions on how to change her name, which is not what I am looking for. I understand that this is likely my fault, but I would expect the designers to make it simpler to locate the necessary instructions. It may not be a major issue for those familiar with technology, but it is a challenge for me.

We tried switching them around, but there was no difference. As a result, they are now just collecting dust, disconnected.

verified_reviews: I received my Echo Dot today in good condition, but be advised: I paid $29.99 for it and Amazon has (as of this writing) raised the price to $39.99, so do your research before buying so you can get a good deal!Set up with the Dot went simple enough — plug it in, follow the app instructions... except initially it took a while to actually show up in my iPhone’s WiFi settings. I called Amazon customer service, and I dunno what it is, but lately I’ve been getting terrible support. The guy that took my call just rambled off a (completely unhelpful) script and I ended up setting up the Dot while he was in the middle of his spiel.I’m not sure if this is the norm or if it’s because this is refurbished, but the Dot has a pretty finicky wifi range and randomly disconnects even though the app shows that the range of my 5GHz connection is strong. Reconnecting is a pain each time as well.All that said, when Alexa works, she works amazingly well. I don’t have a speaker hooked up to it, but one thing I really enjoy is the mic’s range and sensitivity. One of the more annoying limitations of Apple’s Siri is that when she’s playing audio through device speakers (music, podcasts, etc), the “Hey Siri” feature is all but useless. Alexa has no problem hearing me over whatever is playing at the time, and with amazingly fast responsiveness too. I haven’t tried this with louder speakers yet, so I’m not sure if this will continue to hold true.Setting up Alexa to control all my wireless devices was a breeze, albeit with limitations — support for Arlo devices is nil, and if you have special settings for your LED devices (eg. rainbow effects), Alexa can’t handle them, she only knows how to change solid colors and brightness levels.All in all, my rating would’ve been lower had I not gotten a decent price on this item. If the connectivity problems persist, I may have to exchange/return this item. I don’t want to though — Alexa’s kind of growing on me.
paraphrased_reviews: I recently got my Echo Dot and it was in good condition. However, I paid $29.99 for it and Amazon has since increased the price to $39.99, so do your research before buying to ensure you get a good deal. Setting up the Dot was quite simple - just plug it in and follow the app instructions. Initially, it took a while for it to show up in my iPhone's WiFi settings. When I called Amazon customer service, the person I spoke to was not very helpful and just read out a script. The Dot's WiFi range is quite finicky and it tends to disconnect randomly even though the app shows that the range of my 5GHz connection is strong. Reconnecting is also a bit of a hassle. On the plus side, Alexa is very responsive and I like the mic's range and sensitivity. Alexa can also hear me over whatever audio is playing, which is a huge improvement over Siri. Setting up Alexa to control my wireless devices was fairly easy, but it does have its limitations. For example, it does not support Arlo devices and it can only change solid colors and brightness levels for LED devices. Overall, I'm happy with my purchase, but if the connectivity problems persist, I may have to exchange or return the item.

verified_reviews: This is a great device. We mainly use it to verbally add things to the shopping list, but occasionally use any number of the "fun" things you can program it to do, like go to Red Alert or make the TARDIS land (yes, we're a house of geeks... we even chose the wake-word to be "Computer" instead of "Alexa". Now we just need Majel Barret's voice and I will be in geek heaven.) ;)It's not as easy to get my Premium Spotify to work properly with it, and still not sure how we can get multiple music accounts attached so we can listen to different music in different rooms, but so far it's still been worth it. I am often asking it the time, the weather, it even gives us a news briefing. We also use it as an intercom system which has been really awesome. Plus it's fun knowing the NSA is listening to everything.

I would be in heaven if Majel Barret's voice was the one giving us the commands). Unfortunately, getting my Premium Spotify to work with it has been a bit of a hassle and I haven't figured out how to get multiple music accounts so different people in different rooms can listen to different music. Still, it's been worth it. I often ask it for the time and the weather, and it even gives us a news briefing. We also use it as an intercom system, which has been really useful. verified_reviews: The Echo is an amazing device.  Many times it seems very intuitive.  But at other times I ask for something that seems clear and simple and get no result.  Installation was fairly straightforward, but I messed up several times simply because I thought a step was complete when it wasn't.  This actually made me lose ground until I figured that out.  My advice is to be patient; the app will let you know when you can move on to the next step.My biggest issue of the moment is that we have several Echo devices in our home and I would like to use them as intercoms (which I am told can be done).  However, I can't make any of the Echos aware of the others existence.  When I ask Alexa how to do this she answers about instructions how to change her name.  I know this is likely my fault, but I would think the designers would anticipate this and make it easier to find the needed instructions.  A small deal for many device savvy people, but a challenge for me.
paraphrased_reviews: The Echo is an incredible invention that often appears to be very intuitive. However, there have been times when I have asked for something that should be simple, yet I get no response. The installation process was not difficult, but I made some errors because I assumed I had completed a step when I had not. My suggestion is to be patient; the app will tell you when you can progress to the next stage. My current issue is that I have several Echo devices in my home and I would like to use them as intercoms, which I understand is possible. However, I can't make the Echo devices aware of each other. When I ask Alexa how to do this, she responds with instructions on how to change her name. I realise this is probably my own fault, but I would have expected the designers to anticipate this and make it easier to find the necessary instructions. It may not be a big deal for those who are tech-savvy, but it is proving to be a challenge for me.

verified_reviews: I love the Echo Spot. This bedside alarm clock size device can do what theEcho Show can do. The stand/base for the Spot is definitely worth buying too. All in all, I'm really happy with the Echo Spot and I would highly recommend it to anyone.

verified_reviews: I love this little Spot more than I thought I would. The sound is great for such a little thing...my music plays nice and loud and clear. I love having it in my kitchen but trying to find a place to plug it in is a pain. And it won’t connect to my Bluetooth speaker while playing Amazon Prime Music for some reason, which is a drag when I want to hear it in the dining room during dinner. Of course, if it was CORDLESS I could just bring it with me...otherwise, I absolutely love it and will probably buy another one!

I was so impressed that I convinced my mom to purchase one for my sister's birthday. The only thing that stops me from giving it a full five stars is that it isn't cordless. It is great to have it in my kitchen but the hassle of finding a plug to connect it to is a nuisance. Additionally, it won't connect to my Bluetooth speaker while I am playing Amazon Prime Music in the dining room. If it was cordless, I could easily take it with me. verified_reviews: As an Alexa device, it works just as well as any of the other products.  Unfortunately it doesn't go up from there.  The ability to play videos is very limited. You can't turn off the "Things to try" screen You can turn off the screen scroll, but that defeats the purpose of having the screen.  I don't need to be reminded every 5 seconds what things I can do with Alexa.  I don't need the advertising, especially at the cost of this device.  Overall, its an expensive Alexa device with a screen that's not very useful and annoying. You can turn off the screen scroll, but this defeats the purpose of having the screen in the first place. It is unnecessary to be reminded every five seconds of the things you can do with Alexa, and the device's cost does not justify the advertising. All in all, this is an expensive Alexa device with a screen that is not very useful and is incredibly annoying. I would not recommend this until Amazon improves the screen and makes it actually useful.

verified_reviews: All is fine with the Spot exact for one massive failing.  In order to turn off a repeating alarm in the morning you pretty much have to talk - which is not a thing you usually want to do when first woken up and your bed partner will definitely not like.  YES, you can manually swipe up on the alarm face to dismiss but i) swiping up rather than touching screen when you are half asleep is very difficult and results in setting snooze more than half the time even if you really try to swipe to dismiss and ii) if you do manage to swipe up to dismiss, then you completely delete your recurring alarm.This is especially annoying as Amazon could so easily fix this by simply making touching the screen turn off the alarm but NOT delete it or at least make it a setting to decide whether touching the screen for a recurring alarm snoozes or turns it off.  But as the clock has been out for a year now and they still haven't adding this setting, clearly not going to happen.  This may be the biggest product design screw up Amazon has ever made.
paraphrased_reviews: Everything is great with the Spot except for one major flaw. It is not possible to turn off a repeating alarm in the morning without speaking, which is not something you'd want to do when you first wake up, and it would definitely not be appreciated by your bed partner. It is possible to manually swipe up on the alarm face to dismiss it, but this is difficult to do when you are half asleep, and you end up snoozing it more often than not, even if you try to swipe to dismiss it. Furthermore, if you do manage to swipe up to dismiss it, then you completely delete your recurring alarm. This is particularly frustrating, as Amazon could easily fix this by making it so that touching the screen turns off the alarm without deleting it, or at least make it a setting to decide whether touching the screen for a recurring alarm snoozes or turns it off. However, since the clock has been out for a year now and they still haven't added this setting, it doesn't seem like it's going to happen. This could be one of the biggest product design mistakes Amazon has ever made.

verified_reviews: I got this on Prime day and figured I'd see what all the hype is about.  Honestly I didn't really want to like it as personally bugging my house seems kinda weird, but honestly, I love it.  Like it or not this is the way the world is going, so why not.I loved it so much I ordered 2.  I didn't get the Show because it looks like it came from the 1990's and is downright ugly.  I have no interest on watching anything on these devices anyway, so the Spot's screen does not bother me - although it is very clear.Alexa can hear you from pretty much everywhere.  My favorite part about this is having it in our living room where it's hooked up to our bluetooth soundbar - where I can just say play any song I want and it will.  I guess I could just pick up my smartphone to do that, but you don't know how much easier it is to interact with media using your voice rather than navigating through multiple pages.The one thing that I am not a fan of is the home screen cards do not really rotate that much - they also do not rotate when playing music.  I'd love for it to display the weather as I listen to music.The screen is clear and I also really enjoy Alexa being able to tell me how my commute will be - there is a great skill that you can download that will tell you traffic to 5 different places (that you program and name) so you can say alexa give me traffic to my parents - and she will tell you the best route and time you will arrive in current traffic.  I have this programmed for my parents, fiances parents, work, and her work.  So it really works great.The one thing that I actually preferred the Dot over the Spot is the dot will light up different colors when you have package notifications.. I have not seen the Spot really do much for package notifications yet.  The dot it was very easy to tell when something was delivered.  I would recommend Amazon do exactly what they did for the Dot but on the Spot - the Dot lights up colors - why can't the Spot ?  The same way you command alexa and you get that blue ring, just make that ring yellow when a package is updated for delivery.Overall it's a great device that I am looking forward to integrating my home around.  I'm already looking at dash buttons, smart plugs, etc..- and = when I become a home owner instead of renting where I can't tinker with my thermostat I will be purchasing a Nest down the road for HVAC integration.
paraphrased_reviews: I got this on Prime Day and wanted to see what all the fuss was about. I wasn't sure if I'd like it, as I felt a bit strange about having a device in my house that could be listening to me, but I ended up loving it. It's clear that this is the way the world is moving, so why not get on board? I was so impressed that I even bought two of them. I didn't go for the Show as it looks like something from the 90s and is really ugly. I don't watch anything on these devices anyway, so the Spot's screen doesn't bother me. Alexa can hear you from almost anywhere in the house, and my favorite thing is having it hooked up to our Bluetooth soundbar so I can just ask it to play any song I want. It's much easier than searching through multiple pages on my phone. The one downside is that the home screen cards don't rotate much, and they stay the same even when music is playing. I'd love it if it showed the weather when I'm listening to music. I actually preferred the Dot over the Spot for package notifications, as the Dot lights up in different colors when something is delivered. I haven't seen the Spot do anything like that yet. I'd recommend Amazon make the Spot do the same thing the Dot does - have a yellow ring when a package is on its way. All in all, I'm really looking forward to integrating my home with this device. I'm already looking at Dash buttons, smart plugs, etc. and when I become a homeowner, I'll be getting a Nest for HVAC integration.

verified_reviews: Much easier to use than the dot. It picks up my voice from farther away and the speakers seem a lot cleaner sounding The screen is a nice perk but I only use it at bed time to listen to prime shows before bed, the screen is too small to watch shows..It displays my alarm in print so I know Alexa heard me correctly. and you can make you own clock face with personal pictures.  My only complaint is that they don't add the stand as standard. I didn't need it for my spot at my desk but definitely needed it beside the bed.Many people complain about the basic Alexa program but it is still such new tech that I'm not going to split hairs.  The echo was not as good as my dot and the spot is better than dot.  Alexa gets better over time and the skills are increasing weekly. Now Alexa even tells the difference between my son and my voice. I think Amazon is working overtime on this project. I gave feedback to ask to be able to have self made lists and now you can make and name lists for anything.I am so used to my Alexa that I talk to her even when I'm staying in a hotel and she's no where to be found.  Alexa, what time is it?  ALEXA???!!
paraphrased_reviews: The Echo is much more user-friendly than the Dot. It picks up my voice from farther away and the speakers are much clearer. The screen is a great addition but I only use it at night to listen to Prime shows; it's too small to watch shows. It also displays my alarm in print so I know Alexa heard me correctly and you can create your own clock face with personal images. The only downside is that the stand is not included as standard, so I had to buy one for my bedside. While some people may not be satisfied with the basic Alexa program, I think it is still very new technology and I'm not going to be too critical. Compared to the Dot, the Echo is much better and Alexa is constantly improving, with new skills being added every week. It can even differentiate between my son and my voice. Amazon is clearly putting a lot of effort into this project. I even gave feedback to ask for the ability to make lists and now you can create and name lists for anything. I'm so used to Alexa that I find myself talking to her even when I'm in a hotel and she's not around. Alexa, what time is it? ALEXA???!!

verified_reviews: This is 1 of 6 echo devices in the house and is currently being deployed as a bedside alarm clock.  I use it basically as an echo dot with a clock attached and may occasionally pull up camera video.  Audio quality and screen quality are really are not appropriate for music or watching video.  Much of the time it works well as alarm clock, but there are some serious flaws, particularly if you are the last one to bed or the first to wake.  It doesn’t seem like the engineers actually tested this in a bedroom with 2 people on different schedules.  Try walking into a dark bedroom with a sleeping wife and waking her up by saying “Alexa set an alarm for 5am” and then having Alexa repeat “OK alarm set for 5am.”  Not good.  I suppose you could whisper then fumble for the volume down button but that is stupid.  Plain and simple, this device needs to be brought into the 1990’s and have simple touch screen interface added to set an alarm.  I know there is a cumbersome interface for these situations where one can set an alarm from the alexa app on your phone.  No thanks, if I’m picking up my phone to set an alarm I will just use its built in alarm and save a step.  At least the engineers allow the alarm to be turned off from the touch screen, so for example if you wake up a few minutes early you can cancel the alarm without speaking and waking your spouse.  The interface for using the touch screen to cancel an alarm that has gone off is however not great.  There should be separate snooze and cancel buttons.  Currently a touch snoozes and a swipe cancels.  It is too easy when half awake to snooze when you think you have cancelled.  When the snoozed alarm goes off a few minutes later, my not amused and no longer sleeping wife will let me know by summoning Alexa to turn off the bathroom lights while I’m in the shower.
paraphrased_reviews: This is one of six Echo devices in the house, and it is being used as an alarm clock by my bedside. It functions like an Echo Dot with a clock attached, and I may occasionally use it to pull up camera video. However, the audio and screen quality are not suitable for music or video watching. Most of the time, it works well as an alarm clock, but it does have some significant flaws, especially if you are the last one to go to bed or the first one to wake up. It doesn't seem like the engineers actually tested this device in a bedroom with two people on different schedules. Imagine walking into a dark bedroom with a sleeping partner and saying, “Alexa, set an alarm for 5am,” only to have Alexa repeat, “OK alarm set for 5am.” That is not ideal. You could try to whisper and fumble for the volume down button, but that is still inconvenient. To bring this device into the 1990s, it needs to have a simple touch screen interface added to set an alarm. I know there is a complicated way to do this through the Alexa app on your phone, but that is an extra step. At least the engineers made it possible to turn off the alarm from the touch screen, so if you wake up early, you can cancel the alarm without speaking and disturbing your partner. The interface for using the touch screen to cancel an alarm, however, is not ideal. There should be separate snooze and cancel buttons. Currently, a touch snoozes and a swipe cancels, and it is too easy to snooze when you think you have cancelled when you are half-awake. When the snoozed alarm goes off a few minutes later, my not-amused and no longer sleeping partner will let me know by summoning Alexa to turn off the bathroom lights while I'm in the shower.

However, there is one thing I really dislike and it would prevent me from recommending it to anyone - you can't delete the running suggestions of what to ask Alexa from the nice screen. Unless you turn off the screen completely, which I do when I go to bed. It's unfortunate because it's like a continuously running advertisement or set-up guide, and not attractive. The Echo Show was on sale before Prime Day for less than the Echo, so I thought I was getting a good deal when trying to decide which device to buy. Because of the ever present script, it's not a pleasant device to look at, so I wouldn't buy it again or recommend it - go with the Echo. I may still exchange the product.

verified_reviews: Don't waste your money.  I own an echo gen 1, and echo gen 2 and a dot. They all do a far better job of voice recognition that the Echo Show.  In fact, it is so bad that it is virtually useless.  Also, the speaker is incredibly bass heavy....so much so that it is hard to understand voices.  I've worked to adjust the bass and punch the mids and treble, but it still sounds awful.  Finally, the screen just doesn't add much.  I can't see if from across the room, it rarely activates in any meaningful way, and when it doesn't, it is more of a distraction than a help.(Using FaceTime is so much more practicalthan using the Show.) I'm surprised Amazon didn't make this a little more useful than it is.  Perhaps in the future, but for now, it is a waste of time and money.
paraphrased_reviews: Don't spend your hard-earned money on the Echo Show. I have the first and second generation Echo and a Dot, and they both have significantly better voice recognition than the Show. In addition, the speaker quality is so poor that it is difficult to understand voices, and I have tried to adjust the bass and treble settings to no avail. The screen is also not very useful, as it is too small to be seen from across the room and rarely activates in a meaningful way. FaceTime is a much more practical choice. It's a shame that Amazon didn't make the Show more useful, but as of now it is a waste of time and money.

The sound quality is amazing and the screen resolution is like watching a mini 4K tv.  I love being able to see my timers, events and list instead of having them read to me. I got this on Prime Day and it was worth every penny. When I got the Dot as a gift, I thought it was just a cute novelty that I wouldn't use much. Boy, was I wrong! The Echo is a part of my daily life now and it's made things so much easier.

verified_reviews: So far I’m very pleased with my Echo Show.  The problem is, there’s so much it can do that I haven’t been able to explore the extent of its abilities! I got the special price as part of the Prime Day promotion...and you just can’t beat what you get for the price.  Very pleased with the sound. The video screen is sharp. Sometimes it takes a few tries to get Alexa to perform a command...but as I get to know the system better, I’m hoping that will improve.  One drawback in the music...I’ve noticed a lot of the songs from years past, are re-recordings by the original artist...but not the original recording itself.  Example: Secret Agent Man by Johnny Rivers...a “live”version is used, not the original version.  If I’m going to pay for Prime Music...I’d like to hear the original version of songs...not later recordings.  Or at least give me a choice of what I want to hear.  Otherwise, I am very pleased with my Echo Show.  So pleased in fact, that I bought a second one!
paraphrased_reviews: I have been really pleased with my Echo Show, as it has so many features that I haven't even been able to explore yet. I got a great deal on it during the Prime Day promotion, and the sound and video quality are great. I have found that sometimes it takes a few attempts to get Alexa to understand my commands, but I'm sure that will improve as I become more familiar with the system. The only issue I have is with the music; a lot of older songs are re-recordings by the original artist, not the original version, such as Johnny Rivers' "Secret Agent Man". If I'm going to pay for Prime Music, I would like to be able to hear the original versions of songs, or at least have the choice. Despite this, I am still very satisfied with my Echo Show, so much so that I bought a second one!

verified_reviews: I haven't had my show very long or used it a lot, but I love it! I use it to set timers when cooking because my stove is being finicky and not wanting to work most of the time. I also use it to check for different recipes, listen to music and my all time favorite.... telling everyone it is time for dinner. My son gets a real kick out of that!I know a lot of people are expecting more out of their shows then it is possible to at the moment, but remember the original echo didn't have what it has now when it first came out. I see that Amazon is adding new stuff all the time and soon I am sure it will have all that we want very soon.... maybe even things we haven't thought of!I do wish it was a bit more user friendly. I still haven't figured out how to video chat with my cousin in North Carolina who also has one, and when I tried to call my son's dot it went to video chat immediately, last I looked, dots don't have video screens!Another thing that needs to be addressed is when my husband tried to have the one in our bedroom play thunderstorm sounds to help him go to sleep, it tried to get him to buy an app instead of playing the skill I had enabled that was free. So now he is a bit worried to use it again. That needs to be fixed.I do have to say that all in all I am very happy with my Echo Show!
paraphrased_reviews: Despite not having had it for very long or used it a lot, I find it very useful for setting timers when my stove isn't behaving, looking up recipes, playing music, and my favorite - letting everyone know it's time for dinner! My son gets a real kick out of that.I understand that people may want more from their Echo Show than what is currently available, but it's important to remember that the original Echo didn't have the same features when it was first released. Amazon is constantly adding new features and capabilities, and I'm sure that soon it will have everything we want - and maybe even things we haven't thought of yet.I do wish it was more user-friendly. I still haven't been able to figure out how to video chat with my cousin in North Carolina who also has an Echo Show, and when I tried to call my son's Dot, it went straight to video chat - despite the fact that Dots don't have video screens! Another issue is that when my husband tried to get the Echo Show in our bedroom to play thunderstorm sounds to help him sleep, it tried to get him to buy an app instead of playing the free skill I had enabled. He's now a bit wary of using it again, and this needs to be fixed.Overall, I'm very pleased with my Echo Show!

verified_reviews: I bought this product hoping that Alexa would be pretty well developed and far enough along, therefore expecting her to be responsive. This $100 piece of crap doesnt even know how to respond to a question that amazon themselves told me to ask her. (Echo buttons manual, see Step 3.) The device has potential given it has a big screen, decent sound but for 200 bucks, I would never reccomend it. Even for the $100 I spent, I feel like I got shorted. Oh and lastly, the device is pretty useless without a prime membership. I linked my personal account to it and the thing was literally a decorated bluetooth speaker. I went on the family account (this one) and got it to work minimal. Oh, and even with our prime membership, you have to have a music pass or something that's an extra 3.99 a month, leaving this item a subscription nightmare, and a overpriced, decorated bluetooth speaker in my eyes. I would give it zero stars if I could.
paraphrased_reviews: I purchased this product in the expectation that Alexa would be advanced and able to respond to my questions; however, the $100 device was unable to even understand a question that Amazon themselves said to ask. It has potential with its big screen and sound, but I would never recommend it for the price of $200. I paid $100 for it and feel like I was taken advantage of. To make matters worse, it is virtually useless without a Prime membership. When I linked it to my personal account, it was just a fancy Bluetooth speaker. I did get it to work with our family account, but then I had to pay an extra $3.99 a month for a music pass. This makes it a subscription nightmare and I would give it no stars if I could.

Amazon forces you to view continous spam on the home screen promoting all their Alexa features.  You can turn off many other things in settins, but you cannot turn off "Things to Try".  Instead of a beautiful digital photo screen with weather and time ... we now constantly have a spam ad across the home screen that says, "Try ......".  AMAZON, please listen to your customers and offer a setting to turn off this SPAM!

Amazon does not give you the option to turn off the 'Things to Try' feature on the home screen, meaning that instead of a beautiful digital photo screen with weather and time, we now have a spam advertisement across the home screen. Amazon, please listen to your customers and provide a setting to turn off this spam!

paraphrased_reviews:
the other one

We mainly got this device for our son, who is vision impaired. It has a lot of great features and the setup wasn't too difficult after I set up the first one, but they should make it easier to set up and come with more pre-loaded features. It should be easier to send text messages to friends without them having to download something for it to work, and it should be able to link with email and popular social media sites like Facebook, Twitter, and others. The goal was to get him back connected to the Web by voice so he wouldn't feel left out and isolated. They should also provide a tech support phone number or a way to provide direct help to the Echo so tech support can assist with the setup of the device. I had to ask a friend who is an IT guy to come and help me set up the other one.

verified_reviews: I love my echo plus. I haven't one bad thing to say. It controller music when I need it too. With a great sounding 360 speaker. I also bought a 4k fire TV and it can open Amazon prime video or Netflix at any moment. The included hue lighting makes this product even better. I found myself with a whole array of smart lights perfect for any house or entertainment room. The addition of phone calls on the mic and speaker makes it practical when your busy in the kitchen or on the computer. Alexa will controll it all as soon as you say "Hey Alexa". And if the always on mic concerns you well you can always mute the device. This is a must buy for anyone interested in ease and comfort.

I also purchased a 4K Fire TV, which allows me to access Amazon Prime Video or Netflix with ease. The included hue lighting is a great bonus, giving me the ability to create a smart lighting system for any room in my house. The addition of phone calls on the microphone and speaker makes it very convenient when I'm in the kitchen or working on the computer. Alexa is always ready to take control as soon as I say "Hey Alexa", and if I'm worried about the microphone being always on, I can easily mute the device. All in all, this is a must-have for anyone looking for convenience and comfort.

verified_reviews: I decided to buy smart door lock and decided on getting the Echo Plus to control it.  I chose a Kwikset 888 because Amazon said it was compatible and I bought 2 Dots while I was at it.  And when I posed the question, somebody in the community said it will work with Alexa.  What I didn't know was the Z-wave lock and Zigbee Alexa hub weren't compatible.  Does any body know of a lock that works seamlessly with Echo Plus?  If not, I guess my choices are: 1. Exchange the Plus for a regular Echo and buy a separate hub like Wink.  2. Return the whole Alexa system and get something else.I  don't want to just buy another hub to use along side my Echo Plus or I'll be back here asking how to integrate two hubs.The reason I kept from buying smart systems up to this point  is because I was afraid they wouldn't operate seamlessly and unfortunately I only do enough research after something doesn't work.
paraphrased_reviews: I opted to purchase a smart door lock and chose the Echo Plus to control it. I purchased the Kwikset 888 as Amazon said it was compatible and also got 2 Dots. When I asked the question, someone in the community said it would work with Alexa, but I didn't know that the Z-wave lock and Zigbee Alexa hub were not compatible. Does anyone know of a lock that works perfectly with the Echo Plus? If not, I have two choices: 1. Exchange the Plus for a standard Echo and buy a separate Wink hub. 2. Return the whole Alexa system and get something different. I didn't want to buy another hub to use with the Echo Plus since it would mean I'd be back here asking how to combine two hubs. The reason I haven't bought smart systems until now is because I was scared they wouldn't operate smoothly and I usually only do enough research after something doesn't work.

verified_reviews: I purchased the Amazon Echo Plus on Amazon prime day because I need a hub. I'm in the process of upgrading my home into a smart home. For the same price as some hub's, and even less expensive in some other cases. I got a hub that works with my devices, plus it does a lot more. I haven't even had time to go through all the skills it has, but I've already found myself using many of them. When I started a search for a hub. I wasn't even considering the Echo. In part, because I didn't know it was a hub. But also because I didn't really think I would find much use for another AI system. If you're looking for a hub. Why settle for a plane hub, when you can get a personal assistant that does so much more and yet cost's the same or less than other hubs? Oh! And by the way. For the same price as the Amazon Echo Plus alone. I found one that came bundled with a smart bulb & saw another that came with a smart plug. Given the price of these extras. Well, that just put the Echo Plus over the top.
paraphrased_reviews: I decided to buy the Amazon Echo Plus on Amazon Prime Day because I needed a hub to upgrade my home into a smart home. It was the same price as some other hubs, and even cheaper in some cases. I found the Echo Plus had a lot of extra features that I wasn't expecting. I hadn't even had the chance to explore all of the skills it has, yet I already found myself using many of them. Initially, I wasn't even considering the Echo because I wasn't aware it was a hub and I didn't think I would find much use for another AI system. If you're looking for a hub, why not get one that does more than just the basics for the same or lower price? Plus, I found a bundle that included the Echo Plus and a smart bulb for the same price as the Echo Plus alone. Some bundles even included a smart plug at no extra cost. This made the Echo Plus an even better deal.

verified_reviews: I love everything about it. I love that the echo plus turns on and off my light. It can also dim them with voice commands. I also like listening to my kindle books even the ones that I didn’t purchased  audibles for. I like that it can play my music from Amazon music, pandora, tunein, I heart radio and Spotify. Echo can even play my local radio station. I love that the echo is connected to my TiVo Bolt. This allows TiVo to pause, stop and play whatever I want with a simple voice command. I love that I can reorder items that I purchased on Amazon and that the echo plus notifies me when my order is mailed, when it will be delivered and when the package has been delivered.  The only three dislikes that I have is that if you’re up too close or to far the echo doesn’t respond. So I think they need to improve the microphone. And I wish the speaker was better. The speakers are okay but could be improved. Also I have the echo dot and it never has given me any problems with the internet. Well the other day I received a Red Light Right on my Echo Plus. This error was Sorry I’m having trouble understanding you please try again later. After research online I learned it was a problem connecting to my internet. And it was easy to find this out. And I found it odd that my dot wasn’t having this problem even though they are connected to the same network.
paraphrased_reviews: I absolutely adore my Echo Plus: it can turn on and off my lights, dim them, and even play my Kindle books without needing Audible. It can also play music from Amazon Music, Pandora, TuneIn, I Heart Radio, and Spotify, as well as my local radio station. I also love that I can use it to control my TiVo Bolt and reorder items from Amazon. The only three downsides I've noticed are that the microphone is not very good at picking up my voice if I'm too close or too far, the speaker could be better, and I recently got a 'Sorry, I'm having trouble understanding you' error on my Echo Plus, which I found out was due to an issue with the internet connection. Oddly enough, my Echo Dot was connected to the same network and didn't have any issues.

verified_reviews: I purchased the Echo Plus with the Build-in Hub, so I could have the convenience of asking Alexa to turn my lights and lamps on and off.  Philips Hue Light Bulbs were placed in the fixtures that I wanted Alexa to control and they all work great!  I already had an Echo Dot in my Kitchen/Den area, so I placed the Echo Plus with Hub in my bedroom. My radio and lamps in my Kitchen and Den are controlled with TP-Link plugs.  But, the ceiling light fixtures and lamp in my Den and Bedroom have special Philips Hue Light Bulbs that are controlled by the Hub inside the Echo Plus.  I am able to play music, set my alarm, get weather reports and numerous other things on both devices.  The Echo Dot requires a TP-Link plug to be plugged into it and the Echo Plus requires a special Philips Light Bulbs installed in each light fixture to work..  The only thing I dislike is the high price of the light bulbs required to make the lights work. Regular light bulbs placed in the ceiling light fixtures will not work with Alexa and  the Echo Plus with Hub.  Other than the high price of the bulbs, I love my Echo Plus with built in hub!
paraphrased_reviews: I bought the Echo Plus with the integrated Hub so I could have the advantage of asking Alexa to switch my lights and lamps on and off. I put Philips Hue Light Bulbs in the fixtures I wanted Alexa to control and they all function perfectly. I already had an Echo Dot in my Kitchen/Den area, so I placed the Echo Plus with Hub in my bedroom. The radio and lamps in my Kitchen and Den are managed with TP-Link plugs. The ceiling light fixtures and lamp in my Den and Bedroom, however, have special Philips Hue Light Bulbs that are handled by the Hub inside the Echo Plus. I'm able to play music, set my alarm, get weather reports and do many other things on both devices. The Echo Dot needs a TP-Link plug to be plugged into it and the Echo Plus needs special Philips Light Bulbs installed in each light fixture to work. The only thing I don't like is the high cost of the light bulbs necessary to make the lights work. Regular light bulbs placed in the ceiling light fixtures won't work with Alexa and the Echo Plus with Hub. Other than the expensive bulbs, I adore my Echo Plus with built-in hub!

verified_reviews: When I got this Echo I was excited to have a device with better sound than my Dot and a hub to control some Hue bulbs.What I didn't realize and also wasn't fully communicated to me, is that you can't use Hue bulbs to their full potential with this device. You can only turn on and off the lights and set them to a number of preset colors. You also cannot update the bulbs to the newest firmare which is a security concern for me.Do not buy this if you want a full featured hub for your new IoT devices. If you do, you will end up needing to update to a standalone hub, which makes the hub inside this device redundant and pointless.I still love the echo and have zero complaints about the Alexa functionality or sound quality of this device. I'm only disappointed with the hub's functionalities.
paraphrased_reviews: When I bought this Echo, I was thrilled to have a device with better sound than my Dot and a hub to control some Hue bulbs. I had no clue, however, that its hub capabilities were so limited. You can only turn the lights on and off, and set them to pre-determined colors. You also can't update the bulbs to the latest firmware, which is a security issue for me. If you're looking for a hub with full features for your new IoT devices, I'd advise against buying this Echo. You'll end up needing to buy a separate hub, making the one in this device redundant and pointless. I still like the Echo, and I'm very satisfied with the Alexa functionality and sound quality. The only problem I have is with the hub's functionalities.

verified_reviews: I have been hesitant to purchase anything smart home because I am just not good with electronics. verified_reviews: I'll be returning it.  It's been nothing but annoying.  The hub can't be turned off if not needed and it interferes with my Hue Bridge.  I can't even install Philips lights with it unless I unplug it to do so.  There are plenty of other reviews that go in depth with the issues.  Bottom line is it sucks as a hub.  It doesn't support z-wave and zigbee (which in fairness I knew in advance), but when the one protocol it does support doesn't do many functions that a dedicated one will, what's the point?  I noticed right away that my Philips Hue Bridge supports firmware upgrades to the light bulbs themselves and this doesn't.  I found that rather interesting.

verified_reviews: Works great I bought this Direct from amazon, and I have got to tell you, This item Echo Show and Echo Plus is the best item I have ever had and I am kind of a tech geek. I am a disabled person, and it helps me turn light on and off, and schedule doctor appointments, using google voice phone, and get my medical rides to and from hospitals, plays music on cue from multiple web apps, and watch videos, as well as communicating to my Nurses aide my schedule and calendar of events. I wish there were programs that helped disabled people get these and smart lights. They are literally the best items since chocolate to assist the disabled and literally anybody else who need them. Thank God, no more working my ass off to turn on or off lights. Thank you Amazon. I will save up enough money to buy more gift cards from Affirm.com to purchase 1 more of each and some lights for rest of the house. Jeff Bezos these are awesome items and because of your allowing me to get amazon prime at a lower cost due to disability I was finally able to buy these items on your prime day event. really helped when all you earn a month is $672 on SSDI thank you all again.

verified_reviews: We are a long time Amazon Prime family, many years, but new to the Alexa world and thought the purchase of Alexa Plus, with hub, and included Phillips Hue light bulb would be a great start. Alexa does a lot of good things for us like Alarm in the morning, verbalize books, playing music on command, even linked to my Sirrius/xm account. Good daily stuff. Good sound, but not Bose. But, the ads say "Hub included" so don't need anything else to operate devices. Well, not so. I understand there will be some differences in product device  support. The fact that it came with the Hue light bulb works only for on /off/ dimming of the bulb. The bulb is capable of so much more with the Hue App but the Hue app does not recognize Alexa hub as a bridge. So, it appears you do have to get a Philips bridge to set the bulbs for scenes, time the lights when you are away, set color tones, etc. That can all be done via internet with your phone or tablet away from home. The list goes on for its capabilities but not without its own bridge. Was very disappointed to find that out after the fact, to the point I feel we are being misled by Amazon by included the Hue bulbs without explanation. Maybe throw a good discount my way to get the Hue bridge if I keep the Echo Plus before I invest in more light bulbs.
paraphrased_reviews: We have been a part of the Amazon Prime family for many years, but are new to the Alexa world. We thought that purchasing the Alexa Plus with the hub and Phillips Hue light bulb would be a great start. Alexa does a lot of helpful things for us such as setting alarms, reading books aloud, playing music on command, and linking to our Sirius/XM account. The ads say that the hub is included, so we assumed that we wouldn't need anything else to operate our devices. However, we soon discovered that this was not the case. We understand that there are differences in product device support, but the Hue light bulb only works for turning it on/off and dimming it. The Hue app can do so much more, but it does not recognize the Alexa hub as a bridge. Therefore, we have to purchase a Philips bridge to set the bulbs for scenes, time the lights when we are away, set color tones, and more. We are very disappointed that this was not made clear before we bought the Echo Plus and feel that Amazon is misleading customers by including the Hue bulbs without explanation. We would appreciate it if Amazon offered us a discount to purchase the Hue bridge if we keep the Echo Plus before we invest in more light bulbs.

.

I purchased this product on Prime Day and saved a lot of money. I have three large Bluetooth speakers in my house that I have been using for a while, but the Echo Plus was louder than all three of them at the same time. I was very impressed with its clarity and volume. Unfortunately, you need a paid subscription to some kind of streaming audio service in order to get the most out of the device. It will play Pandora and Spotify, but you're limited in terms of skips and song selection without a subscription. Additionally, it does not support YouTube music or audio. Apple users may be disappointed to see that it's not as convenient as an Apple device. Despite this, I still enjoyed the device, but I'm going to get the DOT instead which has an audio out jack (as does the Echo Plus) and I can just connect it to external speakers.

verified_reviews: I have been thinking about getting this for a long time and was excited when it arrived bundled with a Philip Hue bulb.  The excited ended quickly.  I spend about a total of 4 hours attempting to add this bulb to my Alexa Echo Plus.  Everything I tried, ended in a Discovery Failed message.  I tried to set this up over and over and over again.  I watched YouTube videos.  I read set up websites.  I was the poster child of insanity (doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results).The next day I went onto Amazon to get the tech support.  I was hoping something would be done to make this thing work, but also the problem not being operator error.  Well after 3 tech support staff and 1 hr. and 19 mins. of being on the phone, it still didn't work.  This product has tested my patience.  So far this experience is shifting my mindset from going to a smart home to just kicking it old school.The only reason I gave this two stars is because Amazon will be sending me a different Echo Plus and light bulb.  The problem wasn't the bulb, because before packing up the items, I purchased another bulb and still Alexa couldn't locate this device.I pray the next attempt is successful and then I will revise this rating, but what are the odds that I was shipped a defective Echo?  The support person had the same thought.  Maybe I should be exploring the Google device but I can't get over the look of that hub.  It looks like a defuser.I can't believe I didn't find YouTube videos that show the problems I did.  Everything looked simple and seamless...NOT the experience I had.  OK, I'm done with this review because I spend enough wasted time this weekend already.
paraphrased_reviews: I have been wanting this product for a while, so I was ecstatic when it came with a Philip Hue bulb. However, my excitement quickly faded when I spent four hours trying to link it to my Alexa Echo Plus, only to receive a Discovery Failed message. I tried numerous times and even watched YouTube videos and read set up websites, yet I still couldn't get it to work. I was becoming the poster child of insanity, repeating the same thing over and over and expecting a different result. The following day, I contacted Amazon tech support in hopes that something could be done to make the device work, and not be the result of operator error. After speaking with three tech support staff for an hour and nineteen minutes, it still didn't work. This product has truly tested my patience. I gave it two stars because Amazon is sending me a different Echo Plus and light bulb, but I'm skeptical that I was shipped a defective Echo. I'm considering buying a Google device, but I'm not a fan of the hub's look. I wish I had seen YouTube videos that showed the same problems I encountered. Everything looked so simple and effortless, but that wasn't my experience. I'm done with this review because I've already wasted enough time this weekend.

verified_reviews: I got it to try side by side with the Echo originale. They are essentially the same in dimension, weight and the woofer is the same save for the smaller tweeter point up instead of down and the built in hub. As many folks already pointed out, the hub is not a direct replacement for the Philips Hue, Z wave or anything else. It provides a sub set of features available from the stand alone hub and you ended up losing functionality that you took for granted on the dedicated hub. For me, the voice recognition and music play capability is the same, the original Echo may have an edge on the volume department due to larger speakers. The new Echo plus is priced lower than the original Echo with the built in hub but I don't really need the hub with less functionality. In addition, I don't think that Amazon will have software updates for this hub as other dedicated hub would have so bugs could end up never fixed. My Philips hub gets software update probably once every couple months and it keeps up with the changes in the new bulbs FW and they fixes bugs. Net net for me, this Echo does not do anything more than the original Echo and sound quality is not as good. With the  original Echo available as refurbished I would check that out first before considering this or the new Echo which is clearly inferior to both of these.
paraphrased_reviews: I compared the Echo Plus and the original Echo side by side and found that they were essentially the same in terms of size, weight, and the woofer. The Plus has a smaller tweeter that points up instead of down and has a built-in hub, but it doesn't offer the same features as the dedicated Philips Hue, Z wave, or other hubs. The voice recognition and music play capabilities are the same, but the original Echo may have better sound quality due to its larger speakers. The Echo Plus is cheaper than the original Echo, but I don't need the hub and it doesn't offer the same features. Also, Amazon may not provide software updates for this hub like other dedicated hubs, so any bugs may never be fixed. The original Echo is available as refurbished, so I would look into that before considering the Echo Plus or the new Echo, which is inferior to both of these.

verified_reviews: Incredible piece of technology.I have this right center of my living room on an island kitchen counter. The mic and speaker goes in every direction and the quality of the sound is quite good. I connected the Echo via Bluetooth to my Sony soundbar on my TV but find the Echo placement and 360 sound more appealing. It's no audiophile equipment but there is good range and decent bass. The sound is more than adequate for any indoor entertaining and loud enough to bother neighbors in my building. The knob on the top works great for adjusting volume. This is my first Echo device and I would imagine having to press volume buttons (on the Echo 2) a large inconvenience and not as precise. For that alone I would recommend this over the regular Echo (2nd generation).The piece looks quality and is quite sturdy with some weight on it. The rubber material on the bottom has a good grip on the granite counter-- my cat can even rub her scent on it without tipping it over.This order came with a free Philips Hue Bulb which I installed along with an extra one I bought. I put the 2 bulbs into my living room floor lamp, turned on the light, and all I had to do was say "Alexa, connect my devices". The default names for each bulb was assigned as "First light" and "Second light", so I can have a dimmer floor lamp if I just turned on/off one of the lights by saying "Alexa, turn off the second light". In the Alexa app, I created a 'Group' with "First light" and "Second light" and named the group "The light", so to turn on the lamp with both bulbs shining I just say "Alexa, turn on The light".I was surprised how easily the bulbs connected to the Echo Plus with its built in hub. I thought I would have to buy a hub bridge to connect to my floor lamp power plug. Apparently there is some technology built directly inside the bulb! I was surprised by that. Awesome.You will feel like Tony Stark on this device. I added quite a few "Skills" like 'Thunderstorm sounds' and 'Quote of the day' . Alexa always loads them up quickly. Adding songs that you hear to specific playlists on Amazon Music is also a great feature.I can go on and on and this is only my second day of ownership.I was lucky to buy this for $100 on Prime Day, but I think for $150 is it pretty expensive considering the Echo 2 is only $100. In my opinion, you will be paying a premium for the Echo Plus and you have to decide if the value is there for you:1) Taller and 360 sound unit.2) Volume knob on top that you spin (I think this is a huge benefit over buttons)3) Built in hub for Hue bulbs. After researching more, there are some cons to this setup if you plan on having more advanced light setups. For me and my floor lamp, it's just perfect.I highly recommend it and will buy an Echo dot for my bedroom now.
paraphrased_reviews: This amazing piece of technology is the Echo Plus, which I have in the middle of my living room on a kitchen counter. The sound quality is great, with a good range and decent bass, and the volume knob on the top makes adjusting it very precise. It's sturdy and looks great, and also came with a free Philips Hue Bulb. Connecting the bulbs was easy and I can control them with just my voice. There are lots of features, like adding songs to Amazon Music playlists, and I think it's worth the $150 price tag. I highly recommend it and am now looking at getting an Echo Dot for my bedroom.

The device says it's connected and the app tells me to follow it to continue the set up, but it just keeps rolling the three dots around the screen for about five minutes before it locks up and I have to close the app, restart my phone and the Echo, and try again. I think it's too difficult for someone who isn't tech-savvy, so I'm telling them to send the product back.

verified_reviews: Recently cut the cord on cable television. Needed an easy to install and relatively inexpensive alternative option to fill the gap. Ordered the Amazon Fire Stick from Best Buy. Instructions were short and easy to follow. I was going to order the Amazon Ethernet Adapter because I was worried about wireless speeds in my area, but thought I'd wait and see. Glad I did. Wireless connection has proved almost flawless so far. A few brief hiccups here and there, but I'm convinced that was from the Apps themselves. Don't miss the ridiculously high cable prices and am able to watch most of what I used to watch for a much lower price, which right now is a total of $50 a month. Amazon Fire Stick is limited to 1GB of memory and 8GB of storage. Thought that would be a huge issue when it came to downloading Apps and recording shows. So far it hasn't been any issue at all. The upcoming fall tv schedule, which includes the return of NFL Football, might prove more troublesome when I need to record more often. I'll worry about that then. My only real issue is that you can't really turn it off. The screen remains on and uses up electricity, although probably small amounts. Luckily when you unplug it, all downloaded Apps and recorded shows stay in memory. Not sure what happens when you have something scheduled to record when it's unplugged. Haven't tried it yet, although I don't think it'll be an issue with DirectTV Now, which I'm using right now. So far I'm loving the Amazon Fire Stick. Actually love that Amazon, which I use occasionally, come pre-installed.
paraphrased_reviews: I recently stopped my cable service and was looking for an easy and cost-effective replacement. I ordered an Amazon Fire Stick from Best Buy and the instructions were simple to follow. I was initially going to order an Amazon Ethernet Adapter due to worries about the wireless speeds in my area, but I decided to wait and see. It has worked well thus far, with only a few minor hiccups. I'm now paying only $50 a month for the same content I used to get from cable at an exorbitant price. I was concerned about the 1GB of memory and 8GB of storage but it hasn't been a problem yet. I'm a bit worried about the upcoming fall tv schedule, when I'll need to record more often. The only downside to the Fire Stick is that the screen is always on, using electricity. However, when unplugged, all downloaded Apps and recorded shows remain in memory. I'm not sure what happens if something is scheduled to record when it's unplugged, but I haven't tried it yet. I'm pleased with the Amazon Fire Stick so far, especially since Amazon is already pre-installed.

verified_reviews: What can I say. Well, I’m a  paranoid IT person of 30 years but got hooked on the idea of cloud based home control. So yes I love my echo stuff but, I did create a isolated VLAN on my home network to run the devices including the cheap ones that require you to sign up on some questionable website and download their app. Be carful with these people!  Entering your Wi-Fi password on a site that’s not vetted and your location when the app askes is not a good thing. Don't enter your Wi-Fi password on an untrustworthy site, or give your location when asked by the app. It's best to stick with devices that work directly with the Alexa hub, as Amazon has more control over how sensitive information is handled.

I then tried connecting a speaker through the auxiliary jack, but the WiFi interference caused a horrible buzzing sound that woke me up in the middle of the night. verified_reviews: What can I say. Well, I’m a  paranoid IT person of 30 years but got hooked on the idea of cloud based home control. So yes I love my echo stuff but, I did create a isolated VLAN on my home network to run the devices including the cheap ones that require you to sign up on some questionable website and download their app. Be carful with these people!  Entering your Wi-Fi password on a site that’s not vetted and your location when the app askes is not a good thing. Try to stay with devices that  work directly with the Alexa hub with no third-party app, Amazon has more control of these types of devices and how the  sensitive information is handled.
paraphrased_reviews: I'm an experienced IT person, so I'm naturally a bit paranoid, but I got interested in cloud-based home control. I love my Echo devices, but I made sure to set up a separate VLAN on my network for them and any other devices that require you to sign up on a website and download an app. Be careful with these kinds of sites; entering your Wi-Fi password and your location when the app asks is not a good idea. It's best to stick with devices that work directly with the Alexa hub, as Amazon has more control over how the sensitive information is handled.
